html: Isaiah’s “Babylon” historically encompassed not only the ancient city of Babylon but the entire idolatrous, materialistic empire under Babylon’s influence, including nations in league with Babylon against an ascendant Assyria. Isaiah’s oracles against these nations in chapters 13-23, together with chapter 47 which addresses the Woman Babylon, form Part IV of Isaiah’s Seven-Part Structure whose key themes are humiliation and exaltation. In an end-time context, this Greater Babylon represents a wicked world on the eve of its destruction and resembles John’s “Babylon the Great” (Revelation 17-18).
